Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Three Dimensional Microengineered Diseased Tissue Model to Study Invasive Phenotype of Cancer Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Nikkhah, Mehdi
Proposal Number: 1510700

Cancer cell invasion is a highly orchestrated and complex biological process, which is influenced by a plethora of biophysical and biochemical signals that emerge from the tumor microenvironment. In this project, a team of bioengineers, physicists and cancer biologists aim to develop an innovative platform technology to study the dynamic alterations in breast cancer cells and tumor microenvironment during disease progression. The proposed platform technology is comprised of a tumor model integrated with advanced imaging and measurement techniques. Insight from this research will significantly benefit society in terms of advancing our fundamental understanding of cancer progression to an invasive state. Furthermore, the proposed research plan will provide a foundation for a highly collaborative and teamwork oriented environment to engage students and researchers in science and engineering.

The goal of this project is to develop a novel three-dimensional (3D) microengineered breast tumor model integrated with nanoscale force tomography technique to assess the mechanobiological changes that the cancer cells and their surrounding matrix undergo during tumor progression. By successfully building upon the diseased tissue model, the first objective of this research is to determine whether the biophysical properties of the tumor extracellular matrix, in presence of stromal components, are sufficient to promote cancer cell invasion. The second objective is to determine the dynamic changes in the biomechanical properties of cancer cells, while penetrating through the tumor tissue. Furthermore, this study aims at drawing a direct correlation between the geometrical features of the primary tumor region, invasive activity and biomechanical properties of cancer cells. Novel features of the proposed tumor model include that it is modular and that it enables decoupling and analyzing the effect of various microenvironmental cues on cancer cell invasion. Although this interdisciplinary research focuses on breast cancer, the 3D diseased tissue model along with the quantitative measurement technique is versatile and can be used for studies on other types of cancer as well. In addition, the proposed platform technology has a broad impact to investigate other biological processes related to cell migration and biophysics. With respect to the educational impact, this study will provide a solid foundation for interdisciplinary training in the areas of microscale technologies, tissue engineering and cell biophysics to high school, undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF project titled “Three Dimensional Microengineered Diseased Tissue Model to Study Invasive Phenotype of Cancer Cells”was aimed towards developing novel tumor models to understand the biology for cancer invasion and the subsequent biophysical and biochemical changes in the tumor microenvironment. In this project we developed 3 distinct tumor models, using microengineering techniques and advanced biomaterials, to mimic the spatial architecture of mammary tumor microenvironment. We extensively utilized these platforms to perform mechanistic cellular and molecular level studies that have been instrumental to better understand cancer biology as well as in creation of targeted therapeutics to treat this deadly disease. 

In one of our tumor models, we aimed towards understanding how breast tumor cells interact with stromal cells such as cancer associated fibroblasts (CAFs) to modulate the stiffness of the extracellular matrix (ECM). The platform enabled us to visualize the dynamic in-situ changes in ECM properties during active cancer cell invasion in the presence of stromal cells using nanoindentation techniques such as Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM). Our results suggested that the crosstalk between tumor cells and CAFs is crucial to induce change in matrix properties, and that the tumor cells release crucial soluble factors which signal CAFs to enhance the collagen deposition and matrix stiffness. We further demonstrated successful application of this platform for testing the efficiency of anti-cancer drugs on inhibition of stromal desmoplasia. Specifically, we tested the combinatorial treatment of the anti-fibrotic drug Tranilast and the chemotherapeutic drug Doxorubicin. Our results suggested that when these two drugs are added in combination, the matrix stiffness is only minimally increased. Such alleviation of matrix stiffness further minimized tumor cell proliferation and invasion thereby demonstrating improved efficacy of this treatment strategy.

We also fabricated two microfluidic tumor models to better understand the role of CAFs on cancer invasion as well as visualize tumor cell intravasation. In one of the microfluidic models, we utilized patient- derived CAFs and demonstrated enhanced cancer cell migration in presence of CAFs in terms of speed and persistence, a crucial assessment which was not fully performed in earlier reports. We further performed genomic studies (RNA-Sequencing) to identify the genes that were altered in cancer cells due to the presence of CAFs. Notably, we discovered a novel gene of interest, glycoprotein nonmetastatic B (GPNMB), for its role on enhanced cancer cell migration due to the presence of stromal CAFs. This gene was also found to be clinically relevant since clinical datasets suggested that the expression of GPNMB is positively correlated with tumor stage and that high expression of this gene was also correlated with overall patient survival. Notably, the knockdown of this gene blunted the enhanced invasion of tumor cells. In another project, we extended our studies by aiming to visualize cancer cell intravasation by extending our microfluidic tumor model to a novel three-layer platform comprised of tumor, stromal and vascular entities. Our findings suggested that tumor cells influenced vascular dimensionality and architecture, rendering them more leaky. On the other hand, tumor cells were able to intravasate into the vessels thereby progressing the disease towards a metastatic state.

Overall, our findings from this project helped us in better understanding multiple hallmarks of cancer metastasis including stromal ECM remodeling, cancer cell invasion, and intravasation. We strongly believe that the findings from this project will enable researchers in designing better therapeutics to minimize the spread of tumors. Additionally, the platforms developed in this project can be adapted to various other type of cancers to gain more in-depth mechanistic understanding on metastasis of solid tumors.  In total, this NSF award led to 7 high impact journal articles, 12 conference abstracts and presentations and one issued US patent.  

With respect to educational activities, this project was instrumental in training next generation of graduate and undergraduate students. Through this grant, 4 PhD students, 1 MS student and 7 undergraduate students were mentored by the PI and Co-PI. Both graduate and undergraduate students were provided with the opportunity to present their work in many national level conferences including Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES), ASU Molecular and Cellular Tissue Bioengineering Symposium (MCTB), Biophest and FURI symposium. All the students gained necessary skill sets in terms of device fabrication, hydrogel preparation, imaging and AFM. Three PhD students working under this award have now successfully defended their PhD dissertations and secured excellent postdoctoral positions. All the undergraduate researchers have completed their studies at ASU and have now moved to graduate school for higher education (e.g. Columbia University, Georgia Tech) or industrial sectors. The PI and co-PI also incorporated the outcomes of this research in their graduate level courses. In addition, every year their labs participated in multiple University level outreach and educational activities such as Night of Open Door, Summer Engineering Experience, etc.
